title: 2011–12 UEFA Champions League
text:
The 2011–12 UEFA Champions League was the 57th season of Europe's premier club <a href="Association%20football">football</a> tournament organised by <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a>, and the 20th season in its current <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> format. As part of a trial that started in the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2009–10 UEFA Europa League</a>, two extra officials – one behind each goal – were used in all matches of the competition from the play-off round.
<a href="2012%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20Final">The final</a> was held at the <a href="Allianz%20Arena">Allianz Arena</a> in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, Germany. <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a>'s caretaker manager <a href="Roberto%20Di%20Matteo">Roberto Di Matteo</a> led the club to win their first Champions League title after beating <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a> 4–3 on penalties in the final. As tenants of the Allianz Arena (known as Fußball Arena München for the final), this meant that Bayern were the first finalists to have home advantage since <a href="1984%20European%20Cup%20Final">1984</a>. By winning the tournament, Chelsea earned a berth at the <a href="2012%20FIFA%20Club%20World%20Cup">2012 FIFA Club World Cup</a> and <a href="2012%20UEFA%20Super%20Cup">2012 UEFA Super Cup</a>. <a href="FC%20Barcelona">Barcelona</a> were the defending champions, but were eliminated by the eventual winners Chelsea in the semi-finals.
Association team allocation.
A total of 76 teams participated in the 2011–12 Champions League from 52 UEFA associations (<a href="Liechtenstein%20Football%20Association">Liechtenstein</a> organises no domestic league competition). Associations are allocated places according to their 2010 <a href="UEFA%20country%20coefficient">UEFA country coefficient</a>s, which takes into account their performance in European competitions from 2005–06 to 2009–10.
Below is the qualification scheme for the 2011–12 UEFA Champions League:
Distribution.
Since the winners of the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2010–11 UEFA Champions League</a>, <a href="FC%20Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, obtained a place in the group stage through their domestic league placing, the reserved title holder spot in the group stage was effectively vacated. To compensate:
Teams.
League positions of the previous season shown in parentheses.
Round and draw dates.
All draws held at UEFA headquarters in <a href="Nyon">Nyon</a>, <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> unless stated otherwise.
Qualifying rounds.
In the qualifying rounds and the play-off round, teams were divided into seeded and unseeded teams based on their 2011 <a href="UEFA%20club%20coefficient">UEFA club coefficient</a>s, and then drawn into <a href="two-legged%20tie">two-legged home-and-away ties</a>. Teams from the same association cannot be drawn against each other.
First qualifying round.
The draw for the first and second qualifying rounds was held on 20 June 2011. The first legs were played on 28 June, and the second legs were played on 5 and 6 July 2011.
Second qualifying round.
The first legs were played on 12 and 13 July, and the second legs were played on 19 and 20 July 2011.
Third qualifying round.
The draw for the third qualifying round was held on 15 July 2011. The first legs were played on 26 and 27 July, and the second legs were played on 2 and 3 August 2011.
The third qualifying round was split into two separate sections: one for champions (called the Champions Route) and one for non-champions (called the League Route). The losing teams in both sections entered the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%23Play-off%20round">play-off round of the 2011–12 UEFA Europa League</a>.
Play-off round.
The draw for the play-off round was held on 5 August 2011. The first legs were played on 16 and 17 August, and the second legs were played on 23 and 24 August 2011.
The play-off round was split into two separate sections: one for champions (called the Champions Route) and one for non-champions (called the League Route). The losing teams in both sections entered the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%23Group%20stage">group stage of the 2011–12 UEFA Europa League</a>.
Group stage.
The group stage features 32 teams, which were allocated into pots based on their 2011 <a href="UEFA%20club%20coefficient">UEFA club coefficient</a>s (except the title holders, <a href="FC%20Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, who were placed in Pot 1 automatically), and then drawn into eight groups of four. Teams from the same association cannot be drawn against each other. The draw was held on 25 August 2011 in <a href="Monaco">Monaco</a>.
In each group, teams play against each other home-and-away in a <a href="round-robin%20tournament">round-robin format</a>. The matchdays are 13–14 September, 27–28 September, 18–19 October, 1–2 November, 22–23 November, and 6–7 December 2011. The group winners and runners-up advanced to the round of 16, while the third-placed teams entered the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%23Knockout%20phase">round of 32 of the 2011–12 UEFA Europa League</a>.
If two or more teams are equal on points on completion of the group matches, the following criteria are applied to determine the rankings (in descending order):
The 32 teams contain eleven former winners of the European Cup/Champions League (40 titles combined), and five teams (<a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a>, <a href="S.S.C.%20Napoli">Napoli</a>, <a href="Trabzonspor">Trabzonspor</a>, <a href="FC%20Viktoria%20Plze%C5%88">Viktoria Plzeň</a> and <a href="FC%20O%C8%9Belul%20Gala%C8%9Bi">Oțelul Galați</a>) which made their début appearance in the group stage. Eighteen UEFA member associations are represented in this group stage: <a href="The%20Football%20Association">England</a> and <a href="Royal%20Spanish%20Football%20Federation">Spain</a> by four clubs, <a href="Italian%20Football%20Federation">Italy</a>, <a href="German%20Football%20Association">Germany</a> and <a href="French%20Football%20Federation">France</a> by three, <a href="Russian%20Football%20Union">Russia</a> and <a href="Portuguese%20Football%20Federation">Portugal</a> by two, while eleven associations are represented by one club, which are all domestic champions except <a href="Trabzonspor">Trabzonspor</a>, which replaced <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20S.K.%20%28football%20team%29">Fenerbahçe</a> due to <a href="2011%20Turkish%20sports%20corruption%20scandal">match-fixing allegations</a>.
Knockout phase.
In the <a href="single-elimination%20tournament">knockout phase</a>, teams play against each other over <a href="two-legged%20tie">two legs</a> on a home-and-away basis, except for the one-match final. The draw for the round of 16 was held on 16 December 2011. The draws for the quarter-finals, semi-finals and final (to determine the "home" team) were held on 16 March 2012. Both draws were assisted by German footballer <a href="Paul%20Breitner">Paul Breitner</a>, the ambassador for the 2012 final.
In the draw for the round of 16, the eight group winners were seeded, and the eight group runners-up were unseeded. The seeded teams were drawn against the unseeded teams, with the seeded team hosting the second leg. Teams from the same group or the same association could not be drawn against each other. In the draws for the quarter-finals onwards, there are no seedings, and teams from the same group or the same association may be drawn with each other.
Round of 16.
The first legs were played on 14, 15, 21 and 22 February, and the second legs were played on 6, 7, 13 and 14 March 2012.
Quarter-finals.
The first legs were played on 27 and 28 March, and the second legs were played on 3 and 4 April 2012.
Semi-finals.
The first legs were played on 17 and 18 April, and the second legs were played on 24 and 25 April 2012.
Final.
The final was played on 19 May 2012 at the <a href="Allianz%20Arena">Allianz Arena</a> in <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, Germany.
Statistics.
Statistics exclude qualifying rounds and play-off round.
